body_text:
I'm not sure if disabling a recipe should automatically remove it's approval. For example, if we want to update the action code, we have to disable all recipes using an action, update it, and then re-enable them. In other cases we might want to temporarily disable a recipe and then re-deploy it.
I guess the real question here is: What is approval approving of? Is it simply reviewing a given configuration for a recipe and verify that it is good? That'd be the Github model; require approval when the code changes, but don't require peer approval to deploy / rollback the code after it's been merged. In that model we'd remove the approval when a recipe changes but not when it is disabled.
Or are we approving the intent to activate a recipe? Which means that we need approval every time we ever want to deploy a recipe, even if it's configuration hasn't changed.
This probably needs some feedback from User Advocacy.
